articleContent.title: Arpeggio: 9th in F (Shape: D)
articleContent.content:
# Arpeggio: 9th in F (Shape: D)

## Brief Overview
This arpeggio is structured as a 9th chord in the key of F, played in the shape of a D major chord. It consists of the notes F, A, C, E, and G.

## Notes and Intervals
- F (Root)
- A (Major 3rd)
- C (Perfect 5th)
- E (Dominant 7th)
- G (Major 9th)

## Genre and Musical Flavor
This arpeggio, being a 9th chord, is often used in jazz, R&B, and soul music genres. It adds a lush and colorful sound to the harmony, creating a sense of sophistication and depth to the music. The 9th interval gives the chord an extension beyond the basic triads, providing a more complex and expressive quality to the music.

## Example Songs
1. **"All of Me" by John Legend** - This song features the 9th chord arpeggio in various parts of the piano accompaniment, adding a rich and soulful texture to the music.
   
2. **"So What" by Miles Davis** - In this jazz classic, you can hear the 9th chord arpeggio being used in the improvisational sections, showcasing its versatility and harmonic richness.
   
3. **"Ain't No Sunshine" by Bill Withers** - The use of 9th chords, including the arpeggio in question, can be found in the chord progressions of this iconic soul song, contributing to its emotional and melodic appeal.
